awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Energy-Efficient Datacenters with Wireless Interconnection Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal aim of this CAREER: Energy-Efficient Datacenters with Wireless Interconnection Networks project is to establish design principals of a wireless datacenter by integrating intra- and inter-chip wireless networks. Computing machinery around the world consumes staggering amounts of energy. According to the NY Times in September 2012, digital warehouses like datacenters use thirty billion watts of electricity, which is equivalent to the output of thirty nuclear power plants. Networked computing elements are omnipresent in all computing machinery like datacenters, servers and High Performance Computing (HPC). Tens to thousands of multicore chips are interconnected to form an entire datacenter making the role of the network paramount in the performance and energy efficiency of the entire system.
 
Data transfer between cores or memory components in different chips in large computing machinery need to traverse various interconnection technologies at the different levels of the network, often requiring change of switching protocols thus resulting in overheads. More importantly, according to the International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors (ITRS), the pitch of the interchip interconnects is not scaling as fast as the pitch of on-chip interconnects, resulting in a performance gap in the future. Additionally, the wiring complexity of both on-chip and off-chip interconnects exacerbates the problem by posing design challenges, crosstalk and signal integrity issues. Recent research envisions on-chip wireless interconnects using millimeter-wave (mm-wave) technologies for designing Network-on-Chips, which are significantly more energy-efficient compared to traditional architectures. On the other hand in recent years considerable research has been done to develop wireless datacenters using the same 60GHz unlicensed wireless spectrum. The integrated architecture proposed in this work will be capable of establishing wireless routes between communicating processing cores in a datacenter.
 
This highly interdisciplinary project will engage experts from the disciplines of computer engineering, computer science and electrical engineering from both academia and industry. Using concepts and technologies from various domains like computer architecture, communication, integrated circuit packaging and datacenters, the project will establish methodologies for wireless interconnections in large-scale computing warehouses to decrease their energy consumption and carbon footprint, ultimately resulting in a green and sustainable computing paradigm.

por.por_cntn:
The principal aim of this CAREER: Energy-Efficient Datacenters with Wireless Interconnection Networks project is to establish design principals of a wireless datacenter by integrating intra- and inter-chip wireless networks. Computing machinery around the world consumes staggering amounts of energy. Tens to thousands of multicore chips are interconnected to form an entire datacenter making the role of the network paramount in the performance and energy efficiency of the entire system. By designing miniature wireless interconnects in high frequency bands such as 60GHz millimeterwave frequencies we were able to reduce the energy consumption by orders of magnitude compared to traditional wired interconnect systems. Due to the support for multicast/broadcast traffic in the wireless interconnects new benefits to programming paradigms were unlocked as these are very critical control messages which are very latency-critical.

The intellectual challenges overcome through this research are the design of miniature (mcro-scale) wireless interconnects spanning distances of 10mm (single-chip) to 10m (datacenter). These environments are dense with metallic structures (wires or cabinets) and require high Gigabits per second data transfer rates with an energy consumption of less than 1pJ/bit. These extreme performance demands make the research extremely challenging but were comprehensively accomplished in this project. In addition, we investigated security and privacy of such wireless networks and mechanisms to defend against possible common attacks like jamming and eavesdropping. We also extended the work by investigating an alternative processing paradigm such as in-memory processing that alleviates the dependence on interconnects.

In terms of broader impacts an energy-efficiency computing platform can greatly contribute to making computing more sustainable without a large impact and need for energy sources. This in turn will democratize access to computing platforms by reducing operational cost and impact of computing. Four PhD students and several other graduate and undergraduate students including those from underrepresented backgrounds were involved with the project that had a positive impact on their careers where they are all employed gainfully in their area of expertise including a soon to be tenure-track faculty position. New curriculum including a new course on multicore processor design and test was developed and delivered over several years.
